column1: Melbourne ( (listen) MEL-bərn; Woiwurrung: Naarm) is the capital and most-populous city of the Australian state of Victoria
column2: and the second-most populous city in Australia and Oceania. Its name refers to an urban agglomeration of 9
column5: comprising a metropolitan area with 31 municipalities
column6: and is also a common name for its city centre. The city occupies much of the coastline of Port Phillip bay and spreads into the Hinterland towards the Dandenong and Macedon ranges
column7: Mornington Peninsula and Yarra Valley. It has a population of 5 million (19% of the population of Australia)
column8: and its inhabitants are referred to as "Melburnians".Home to Indigenous Australians for over 40
column9: 000 years
column10: the Melbourne area served as a popular meeting place for local Kulin nation clans. A short-lived penal settlement was established at Port Phillip
column11: then part of the British colony of New South Wales
column13: but it was not until 1835
column14: with the arrival of free settlers from Van Diemen’s Land (modern-day Tasmania)
column15: that Melbourne was founded. It was incorporated as a Crown settlement in 1837
column16: and named Melbourne in honour of the then British Prime Minister
column19: four years after Queen Victoria declared it a city
column20: Melbourne became the capital of the new colony of Victoria. In the wake of the 1850s Victorian gold rush
column21: the city entered a lengthy boom period that
column23: had transformed it into one of the world's largest and wealthiest metropolises. After the federation of Australia in 1901
column24: it served as the interim seat of government of the new nation until Canberra became the permanent capital in 1927. Today
column25: it is a leading financial centre in the Asia-Pacific region and ranks 15th in the Global Financial Centres Index.Melbourne is home to many of Australia's best-known landmarks
column26: such as the Melbourne Cricket Ground
column27: the National Gallery of Victoria and the World Heritage-listed Royal Exhibition Building. Noted for its cultural heritage
column28: the city gave rise to Australian rules football
column30: and has more recently been recognised as a UNESCO City of Literature and a global centre for street art
column31: live music and theatre. It hosts major annual international events
column32: such as the Australian Grand Prix and the Australian Open
column33: and also hosted the 1956 Summer Olympics and the 2006 Commonwealth Games. Melbourne consistently ranked as the world's most liveable city for much of the 2010s.Melbourne Airport
column35: is the second busiest airport in Australia
column36: and the city's port is the nation's busiest seaport. Its main metropolitan rail terminus is Flinders Street station and its main regional rail and road coach terminus is Southern Cross station. It also has Australia's most extensive freeway network and the largest urban tram network in the world.

column1: The decade of the 1880s saw extraordinary growth: consumer confidence
column2: easy access to credit
column3: and steep increases in land prices led to an enormous amount of construction. During this "land boom"
column4: Melbourne reputedly became the richest city in the world
column5: and the second-largest (after London) in the British Empire.The decade began with the Melbourne International Exhibition in 1880

column1: In 1885 visiting English journalist George Augustus Henry Sala coined the phrase "Marvellous Melbourne"
column2: which stuck long into the twentieth century and which Melburnians still use today. Melbourne's land-boom reached a peak in 1888
column3: fuelled by consumer confidence and escalating land-value. As a result of the boom
column5: grand edifices
column7: coffee palaces
column8: terrace housing and palatial mansions proliferated in the city. The establishment of a hydraulic facility in 1887 allowed for the local manufacture of elevators
column9: resulting in the first construction of high-rise buildings; most notably the APA Building
column10: amongst the world's tallest commercial buildings upon completion in 1889. This period also saw the expansion of a major radial rail-based transport network.In 1888 the Exhibition Building hosted a second event
column11: even larger than the first: the Melbourne Centennial Exhibition. This spurred the construction of numerous hotels
column12: including the 500-room Federal Hotel
column13: The Palace Hotel in Bourke Street (both since demolished)
column14: and the doubling in size of the Grand (Windsor).A brash boosterism that had typified Melbourne during this time ended in the early 1890s with a severe economic depression
column15: sending the local finance- and property-industries into a period of chaos
column16: during which 16 small "land banks" and building societies collapsed
column17: and 133 limited companies went into liquidation. The Melbourne financial crisis was a contributing factor in the Australian economic depression of the 1890s and in the Australian banking crisis of 1893. The effects of the depression on the city were profound
column18: with virtually no new construction until the late 1890s.

column1: At the time of Australia's federation on 1 January 1901
column2: Melbourne became the seat of government of the federation. The first federal parliament was convened on 9 May 1901 in the Royal Exhibition Building
column3: subsequently moving to the Victorian Parliament House where it was located until 1927
column4: when it was moved to Canberra. The Governor-General of Australia resided at Government House in Melbourne until 1930 and many major national institutions remained in Melbourne well into the twentieth century.

column1: In the immediate years after World War II
column2: Melbourne expanded rapidly
column3: its growth boosted by post-war immigration to Australia
column4: primarily from Southern Europe and the Mediterranean. While the "Paris End" of Collins Street began Melbourne's boutique shopping and open air cafe cultures
column5: the city centre was seen by many as stale—the dreary domain of office workers—something expressed by John Brack in his famous painting Collins St.
column7: Melbourne was considered Australia's "industrial heartland".

column1: Height limits in the CBD were lifted in 1958
column2: after the construction of ICI House
column3: transforming the city's skyline with the introduction of skyscrapers. Suburban expansion then intensified
column4: served by new indoor malls beginning with Chadstone Shopping Centre. The post-war period also saw a major renewal of the CBD and St Kilda Road which significantly modernised the city. New fire regulations and redevelopment saw most of the taller pre-war CBD buildings either demolished or partially retained through a policy of facadism. Many of the larger suburban mansions from the boom era were also either demolished or subdivided.

column1: To counter the trend towards low-density suburban residential growth

column3: which resulted in demolition of many neighbourhoods and a proliferation of high-rise towers. In later years
column4: with the rapid rise of motor vehicle ownership
column5: the investment in freeway and highway developments greatly accelerated the outward suburban sprawl and declining inner city population. The Bolte government sought to rapidly accelerate the modernisation of Melbourne. Major road projects including the remodelling of St Kilda Junction
column6: the widening of Hoddle Street and then the extensive 1969 Melbourne Transportation Plan changed the face of the city into a car-dominated environment.Australia's financial and mining booms during 1969 and 1970 resulted in establishment of the headquarters of many major companies (BHP Billiton and Rio Tinto
column7: among others) in the city. Nauru's then booming economy resulted in several ambitious investments in Melbourne
column8: such as Nauru House. Melbourne remained Australia's main business and financial centre until the late 1970s
column9: when it began to lose this primacy to Sydney.Melbourne experienced an economic downturn between 1989 and 1992
column10: following the collapse of several local financial institutions. In 1992
column11: the newly elected Kennett government began a campaign to revive the economy with an aggressive development campaign of public works coupled with the promotion of the city as a tourist destination with a focus on major events and sports tourism. During this period the Australian Grand Prix moved to Melbourne from Adelaide. Major projects included the construction of a new facility for the Melbourne Museum

column1: Melbourne is in the southeastern part of mainland Australia
column2: within the state of Victoria. Geologically
column3: it is built on the confluence of Quaternary lava flows to the west
column5: and Holocene sand accumulation to the southeast along Port Phillip. The southeastern suburbs are situated on the Selwyn fault which transects Mount Martha and Cranbourne.

column1: Melbourne has a temperate oceanic climate (Köppen climate classification Cfb) with warm to hot summers and mild winters. Melbourne is well known for its changeable weather conditions
column2: mainly due to it being located on the boundary of hot inland areas and the cool southern ocean. This temperature differential is most pronounced in the spring and summer months and can cause strong cold fronts to form. These cold fronts can be responsible for varied forms of severe weather from gales to thunderstorms and hail
column3: large temperature drops and heavy rain. Winters
column5: are usually very stable
column6: but rather damp and often cloudy.

column1: Port Phillip is often warmer than the surrounding oceans and/or the land mass
column2: particularly in spring and autumn; this can set up a "bay effect" similar to the "lake effect" seen in colder climates where showers are intensified leeward of the bay. Relatively narrow streams of heavy showers can often affect the same places (usually the eastern suburbs) for an extended period
column3: while the rest of Melbourne and surrounds stays dry. Overall
column5: owing to the rain shadow of the Otway Ranges
column6: nonetheless drier than average for southern Victoria. Within the city and surrounds
column7: rainfall varies widely
column8: from around 425 millimetres (17 in) at Little River to 1
column9: 250 millimetres (49 in) on the eastern fringe at Gembrook. Melbourne receives 48.6 clear days annually. Dewpoint temperatures in the summer range from 9.5 to 11.7 °C (49.1 to 53.1 °F).Melbourne is also prone to isolated convective showers forming when a cold pool crosses the state
column10: especially if there is considerable daytime heating. These showers are often heavy and can include hail
column11: squalls
column12: and significant drops in temperature
column13: but they often pass through very quickly with a rapid clearing trend to sunny and relatively calm weather and the temperature rising back to what it was before the shower. This can occur in the space of minutes and can be repeated many times a day
column14: giving Melbourne a reputation for having "four seasons in one day"
column15: a phrase that is part of local popular culture. The lowest temperature on record is −2.8 °C (27.0 °F)
column16: on 21 July 1869. The highest temperature recorded in Melbourne city was 46.4 °C (115.5 °F)
column17: on 7 February 2009. While snow is occasionally seen at higher elevations in the outskirts of the city
column18: it has not been recorded in the Central Business District since 1986.The average temperature of the sea ranges from 14.6 °C (58.3 °F) in September to 18.8 °C (65.8 °F) in February; at Port Melbourne
column19: the average sea temperature range is the same.

column1: On the back of the 1850s gold rush and 1880s land boom

Very little remains of Melbourne's pre-gold rush architecture; St James Old Cathedral (1839) and St Francis' Church (1845) are among the few examples left in the CBD. Many of the CBD's Victorian boom-time landmarks were also demolished in the decades after World War II
column8: including the Federal Coffee Palace (1888) and the APA Building (1889)

column1: The governance of Melbourne is split between the government of Victoria and the 27 cities and four shires that make up the metropolitan area. There is no ceremonial or political head of Melbourne
column2: but the Lord Mayor of the City of Melbourne often fulfils such a role as a first among equals
column3: particularly when interstate or overseas.The local councils are responsible for providing the functions set out in the Local Government Act 1989 such as urban planning and waste management. Most other government services are provided or regulated by the Victorian state government
column4: which governs from Parliament House in Spring Street. These include services associated with local government in other countries and include public transport
column5: main roads
column7: policing
column8: education above preschool level
column9: health and planning of major infrastructure projects. The state government retains the right to override certain local government decisions
column10: including urban planning
column11: and Melburnian issues often feature prominently in state election.

column2: Melbourne ties with Canberra in first place for the highest male life expectancy (80.0 years) and ranks second behind Perth in female life expectancy (84.1 years).
Melbourne has a high dependency on the automobile for transport
column3: particularly in the outer suburban areas where the largest number of cars are bought
column4: with a total of 3.6 million private vehicles using 22
column7: and one of the highest lengths of road per capita in the world. The early 20th century saw an increase in popularity of automobiles
column8: resulting in large-scale suburban expansion and a tendency towards the development of urban sprawl–like all Australian cities
column9: inhabitants would live in the suburbs and commute to the city for work. By the mid 1950s there was just under 200 passenger vehicles per 1000 people
column10: and by 2013 there was 600 passenger vehicles per 1000 people. Today it has an extensive network of freeways and arterial roadways used by private vehicles including freight as well as public transport systems including buses and taxis. Major highways feeding into the city include the Eastern Freeway
column11: Monash Freeway and West Gate Freeway (which spans the large West Gate Bridge)
column12: whilst other freeways circumnavigate the city or lead to other major cities
column13: including CityLink (which spans the large Bolte Bridge)
column14: Eastlink
column17: Tullamarine Freeway (main airport link) and the Hume Freeway which links Melbourne and Sydney.Melbourne has an integrated public transport system based around extensive train
column19: bus and taxi systems. Flinders Street station was the world's busiest passenger station in 1927 and Melbourne's tram network overtook Sydney's to become the world's largest in the 1940s. From the 1940s
column20: public transport usage in Melbourne declined due to a rapid expansion of the road and freeway network
column21: with the largest declines in tram and bus usage. This decline quickened in the early 1990s due to large public transport service cuts. The operations of Melbourne's public transport system was privatised in 1999 through a franchising model
column22: with operational responsibilities for the train
column23: tram and bus networks licensed to private companies. After 1996 there was a rapid increase in public transport patronage due to growth in employment in central Melbourne
column24: with the mode share for commuters increasing to 14.8% and 8.4% of all trips. A target of 20% public transport mode share for Melbourne by 2020 was set by the state government in 2006. Since 2006 public transport patronage has grown by over 20%.

column1: The Melbourne rail network dates back to the 1850s gold rush era
column2: and today consists of 218 suburban stations on 16 lines which radiate from the City Loop
column3: a mostly-underground subway system around the CBD. Flinders Street station
column5: serves the entire network
column6: and remains a prominent Melbourne landmark and meeting place. The city has rail connections with regional Victorian cities
column7: as well as direct interstate rail services which depart from Melbourne's other major rail terminus
column8: Southern Cross station
column9: in Docklands. The Overland to Adelaide departs twice a week
column10: while the XPT to Sydney departs twice daily. In the 2017–2018 financial year
column11: the Melbourne rail network recorded 240.9 million passenger trips
column12: the highest ridership in its history. Many rail lines
column13: along with dedicated lines and rail yards
column14: are also used for freight.

column1: Melbourne's tram network dates from the 1880s land boom and
column2: as of 2019
column3: consists of 250 km (155.3 mi) of double track
column5: 25 routes
column7: 763 tram stops
column8: making it the largest in the world. In 2017–2018
column9: 206.3 million passenger trips were made by tram. Around 75 per cent of Melbourne's tram network shares road space with other vehicles
column10: while the rest of the network is separated or are light rail routes. Melbourne's trams are recognised as iconic cultural assets and a tourist attraction. Heritage trams operate on the free City Circle route
column11: intended for visitors to Melbourne
column12: and heritage restaurant trams travel through the city and surrounding areas during the evening. Melbourne is currently building 50 new E Class trams with some already in service in 2014. The E Class trams are about 30 metres long and are superior to the C2 class tram of similar length. Melbourne's bus network consists of almost 300 routes which mainly service the outer suburbs and fill the gaps in the network between rail and tram services. 127.6 million passenger trips were recorded on Melbourne's buses in 2013–2014
column13: an increase of 10.2 percent on the previous year.Ship transport is an important component of Melbourne's transport system. The Port of Melbourne is Australia's largest container and general cargo port and also its busiest. The port handled two million shipping containers in a 12-month period during 2007
column14: making it one of the top five ports in the Southern Hemisphere. Station Pier on Port Phillip Bay is the main passenger ship terminal with cruise ships and the Spirit of Tasmania ferries which cross Bass Strait to Tasmania docking there. Ferries and water taxis run from berths along the Yarra River as far upstream as South Yarra and across Port Phillip Bay.

column1: Melbourne has four airports. Melbourne Airport
column2: at Tullamarine
column3: is the city's main international and domestic gateway and second busiest in Australia. The airport is home base for passenger airline Jetstar Airways and cargo airlines Australian air Express and Toll Priority; and is a major hub for Qantas and Virgin Australia. Avalon Airport
column5: is a secondary hub of Jetstar. It is also used as a freight and maintenance facility. Buses and taxis are the only forms of public transport to and from the city's main airports. Air Ambulance facilities are available for domestic and international transportation of patients. Melbourne also has a significant general aviation airport
column6: Moorabbin Airport in the city's south east that also handles a small number of passenger flights. Essendon Airport
column7: which was once the city's main airport also handles passenger flights
column8: general aviation and some cargo flights.The city also has a bicycle sharing system that was established in 2010 and uses a network of marked road lanes and segregated cycle facilities.

column1: Water storage and supply for Melbourne is managed by Melbourne Water
column2: which is owned by the Victorian Government. The organisation is also responsible for management of sewerage and the major water catchments in the region as well as the Wonthaggi desalination plant and North–South Pipeline. Water is stored in a series of reservoirs located within and outside the Greater Melbourne area. The largest dam
column3: the Thomson River Dam
column5: is capable of holding around 60% of Melbourne's water capacity
column6: while smaller dams such as the Upper Yarra Dam
column7: Yan Yean Reservoir
column8: and the Cardinia Reservoir carry secondary supplies.
